text: Your Friday Evening BriefingHere’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
Listen to ‘The Daily’Special Edition: The pandemic reaches the president.
Listen to ‘The Argument’Opinion writers on the debate, Amy Coney Barrett and Trump’s taxes.
A visual guide to the president’s movements and contacts in the days before he announced his results.
Republicans vowed to press ahead with an election-season confirmation, even with the president ill and a coronavirus outbreak that has spread to the Senate.
The Constitution says the vice president is next in line if the president dies or can no longer serve, but things get murkier from there.
The anchor, who sat about 12 feet from the president at Tuesday’s debate, also criticized a Trump pandemic adviser.
Some politicians who have had the coronavirus have changed their views on the pandemic.
Both sides in the race for the White House are confronting a wrenching series of strategic choices just one month before Election Day.
From Daily Distortions, our project on misinformation: There’s no evidence to support the view, but it shows liberals’ distrust in the White House.
For all of the tumult of the race and other currents battering the country, the issue of the virus has never retreated as the overwhelming factor.
Job Gains Are Waning, a Blow to Economic RecoveryPayrolls grew last month, but permanent layoffs are rising, the labor force is contracting and fewer women are employed.
President Trump’s coronavirus infection provided another reason for investors to worry.
A float from the last carnival. It’s unclear when the next parade would be held. Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
Kentucky’s attorney general asked for more time to redact personal information of witnesses from the grand jury discussion about the Breonna Taylor shooting. Xavier Burrell for The New York Times
Nadeen Ashraf, founder of the @assaultpolice Instagram page, at her home in Cairo this month. Sima Diab for The New York Times
The Editorial BoardGet Well, Mr. PresidentThe health of the country’s top leader is a matter of concern for all Americans.
Aaron E. CarrollTesting Was Not Enough to Protect the White HouseThe key to slowing down the spread of infections is to have few, if any, close contacts. There’s just no getting around it.

I Traveled to 52 Places. Then I Discovered N.Y. on My Bike.After a nonstop year of journeying to far-flung destinations for The Times, a well-traveled writer learns to love the local attractions.

What the ‘Cuties’ Critics Can’t See: The Complexities of Black GirlhoodThe Netflix film and a handful of other recent titles movingly explore what it means to come of age at the crossroads of racism and sexism.
Meet Theater’s Most Famous Superfan: Hillary ClintonShe’s been to 39 shows since the 2016 election, and believes Broadway will return. But she doesn’t have the “gumption” to see herself depicted yet.
